SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts lately, experiencing fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating. These symptoms have been present for approximately five weeks. He attributes the symptoms to the change in seasons and recent home construction projects. The patient has been adhering to his medications but admits to struggling with his diet due to the kitchen renovation, leading to eating out more frequently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fever or chills. Positive fatigue and lightheadedness.
• Cardiovascular: No chest pain. Endorses bloating.
• Respiratory: Positive shortness of breath during exertion. Slight cough.
• Gastrointestinal: No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Patient is alert and oriented.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 centimeters.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.

Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%. Mitral regurgitation present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical examination and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Patient to weigh himself daily and report any weight gain or shortness of breath. Order a new echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Patient to continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevations through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was changing a light bulb on a ladder yesterday and had a stumble, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain with flexion and valgus stress. Normal sensation. No calf pain.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the left knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her into a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin, 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food for a 2-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he felt a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved. He reports taking Tylenol, ibuprofen, and using icy heat, which did not provide significant relief. He experienced tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, he admits to having a sweet tooth and not having home-cooked meals in weeks. He plans to improve his diet.

Regarding his hypertension, he monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends. He is taking his medication.

Regarding his osteoarthritis, it gets aggravated occasionally but has been manageable.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Denies chest pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in toes on the right foot, resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of his back reveals pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Decreased range of motion with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

Back X-ray is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing and avoiding strenuous activity.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for strengthening.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: His recent hemoglobin A1c was 8, indicating poor control.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are running on the high side.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee osteoarthritis well.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He is managing his depression well with medication.

Regarding his hypertension, he is taking Norvasc regularly during the business week but admits to occasionally forgetting it on weekends. His blood pressure in the office today is 120/80 mmHg.

The patient had a lobectomy a couple of years ago. He denies any significant shortness of breath, except for occasional difficulty during humid weather and pollen season. He reports running 4-5 miles daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, reports occasional chest pounding during exercise.
• Respiratory: Denies significant shortness of breath.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression, managed with medication.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is managing well with Prozac.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill prescription.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encourage the patient to continue current management strategies.

2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure is controlled in the office today.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.

3. Status post lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is doing well with no significant respiratory issues.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident over the weekend. She reports her finger was bent back while skiing over moguls. The incident occurred on Sunday.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation
Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and everything lines up well.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. If the pain does not improve, the patient is advised to call and return for a follow-up. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia, who presents today for evaluation and management. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. She reports fatigue, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, chills, and increased sensitivity to cold. She also mentions worsening anxiety and depression. She has been anemic since she was 13 years old and had a hysterectomy in 1996. She had a colonoscopy about 5-6 years ago with no significant findings.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Endorses fatigue, fever, and chills.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath and wheezing.
• Neurological: Endorses headaches.
• Psychiatric: Endorses worsening anxiety and depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Patient is alert and oriented.
• Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds.
• Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia, presenting for evaluation and management.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: She has been anemic since she was 13 years old, with recent blood work showing low hemoglobin, stable hematocrit, normal iron labs, and low ferritin. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.
• Additional Testing: We will schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, capsule endoscopy will be considered. We will recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 12 weeks.
• Specialist Referrals: We will refer her to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.
• Patient Education and Counseling: She should continue taking her iron pills with orange juice to enhance absorption. She should follow the bowel prep instructions for her upcoming procedures and contact us with any questions or worsening symptoms.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidentally discovered pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. He was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with worsening headaches over the past few months. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Labs dated 3/3/21, including CBC, UNES, UH, coagulation, and CRP, were all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, with all other results normal. MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are noted.

PAST HISTORY

Unremarkable.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Computer programmer, married for 25 years, recently bought a small house. No history of alcohol, smoking, or recreational drug use.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None.

EXAMINATION

The patient is alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT

Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.

PLAN

1. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision prior to surgery.
2. Schedule transsphenoidal surgery to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa.
3. Counsel the patient on the risks associated with surgery and anesthesia.
4. Monitor the patient's vision post-surgery to assess for improvement.

End of note.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal. She presents as a new patient with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. The patient reports having chest pain in early October 2020, which lasted for four days and resolved on its own. She has not had any chest pain since then. The pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and was sharp in nature. The patient also experienced difficulty swallowing during this time, which has since resolved. She denies any recent abdominal pain and reports normal bowel movements. The patient has been trying to lose weight and has no known family history of GI problems.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdomen
• Examination of Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No pain or tenderness in the lower abdomen.

RESULTS

ER visit in October 2020: EKG and blood tests were normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 53-year-old female who presents with a history of chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020. The chest pain has since resolved, and the patient has not experienced any additional episodes. Possible etiologies include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety. The patient was going through a stressful job transition at the time of the chest pain, which may have contributed to her symptoms.

The patient and the doctor discussed the option of an EGD to evaluate her esophagus and stomach, but given the absence of symptoms for the past three months, the patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and call with any reoccurrence or change. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Possible kidney issues related to Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, who presents today for evaluation of possible kidney issues. She is a twin, born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation, with a birth weight of 4 pounds, 8 ounces. The patient has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently receiving feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. She has also seen a gastroenterologist, allergist, neurologist, orthopedic specialist, ophthalmologist, and audiologist.

The patient's mother reports that Katherine has approximately 8 to 10 wet diapers per day and drinks a significant amount of fluids, including pea protein milk, water, and diluted juice. There is no family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of possible kidney issues. Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature for patients with this syndrome.

• Medical Reasoning: We will obtain a screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today to evaluate for any congenital anomalies or issues related to her syndrome.
• Follow-up: If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location. If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up with nephrology will be needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient's mother understands and agrees with the recommended medical evaluation plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began yesterday morning when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her outstretched arms. She reports that her right wrist started to hurt immediately and became swollen. The patient rates her pain level as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The patient denies any previous injuries to her right arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Mild tingling in fingers, no numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not recorded.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: No carotid bruit, no thyromegaly, no adenopathy.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: No lower leg edema, palpable pulses.
Right Wrist: Obvious swelling and ecchymosis, tenderness on palpation throughout, bony crepitus, pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Able to make a fist but not tightly.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist taken in office today reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively initially with a brace for her right wrist. I have also advised her to undergo surgery as soon as possible to properly align and stabilize the fracture. Post-surgery, the patient will be placed in a brace for approximately six weeks and will attend physical therapy sessions three times per week. The patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in one month to assess her progress and determine if she can proceed with her planned vacation. If her pain does not improve over the next week, she will contact the office and we will re-evaluate her treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports slipping and falling while working on his property a week ago. He felt a pop in his knee and has been experiencing pain since then.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, managed with 20 mg of lisinopril.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chest pain, and shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain, swelling, and discomfort during flexion and extension.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: not provided
Respiration: not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Examination: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, previously known.
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops or rubs.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Right knee pain with flexion and extension. Edema and effusion present. Tender to palpation over the medial aspect of the knee.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. These reveal no evidence of any fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings suggest an MCL strain resulting from the fall.
- Medical Treatment: The patient will take ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and inflammation. He will also wear a knee brace for support and ice the knee for 20 minutes at a time, 3-4 times daily to reduce swelling.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the nature of his diagnosis and the importance of rest, elevation, and avoiding further strain on the knee.

2. Hypertension management.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure was elevated at 150/70 mmHg during the visit, and he has a history of hypertension managed with lisinopril.
- Medical Treatment: The patient will continue taking 20 mg of lisinopril daily. A referral to nutrition will be provided to help improve his diet and potentially reduce his need for medication in the future.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and suspects it might be related. The patient states he is very active and has experienced occasional aches and pains that usually resolve with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant and worsens when pressure is applied, such as when lying on the shoulder. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that her left knee occasionally gives out while walking, causing her to feel like she might fall. The pain is located internally in the kneecap area and comes and goes quickly. The patient denies any history of injury to the left knee and has not taken any medications for pain. She is concerned about her knee giving out during an upcoming trip that involves walking and line dancing.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports taking Farxiga, Amlodipine, Lisinopril, Hydrochlorothiazide, and Metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies right knee pain.

Cardiovascular: Reports controlled blood pressure.

Endocrine: Reports slightly elevated morning blood sugars.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.

Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension, controlled.
3. Diabetes mellitus, slightly elevated morning blood sugars.

PLAN

1. For left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the surrounding muscles.
2. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order a hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to Metformin dosage.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She is currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. Biopsy of a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good family support and positive interactions with nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports minimal cough and sore throat.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting, no difficulty swallowing.
Psychiatric: Mentally strong and emotionally supported.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck
- Examination: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination: Erythema on the anterior side of the left chest, possibly related to radiation.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide and receiving radiation therapy.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen and radiation dose. Repeat imaging after completion of radiation to assess tumor response and potential for surgical removal.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and crackles on lung exam may be due to radiation-induced inflammation.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

3. Sore throat and painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient may have inflammation in the esophagus due to radiation.
- Medical Treatment: In addition to prednisone, prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports frequent colds that tend to linger for a long time, especially during the winter season. No recent history of abdominal infections or diarrhea. Patient recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies. Family generally healthy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient recently traveled to Zambia. Family owns a donut shop.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Stable, no fever.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LABORATORY RESULTS

Consistent with IgA deficiency as noted by PCP.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work is consistent with IgA deficiency. Although it is a common immunodeficiency, the patient does not seem to have frequent infections that would warrant concern.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Explained the nature of IgA deficiency and its potential implications. Advised the patient to watch for infections that do not resolve or any changes in their abdominal tract. Instructed the patient to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.
- Additional Testing: Order further blood work to check for other immunodeficiencies.

2. Type 2 Diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient recently diagnosed and started on metformin.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of moderation in diet and lifestyle changes to manage diabetes.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. He reports that the pain is localized to the inside of his elbow and can radiate slightly into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. The patient has been engaging in pottery activities during the pandemic, which he believes may have contributed to the pain. He rates the pain as a 6/10 and states that it interferes with his daily activities and sleep. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery activities during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Pulses are equal in all extremities.
NEURO: Sensation is normal to light touch distally.
MSK: Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. No pain with supination. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony misalignment.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis. The patient is advised to rest the affected elbow and wear a sling while awake. He is also instructed to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day and take ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for a full week. The patient is advised to avoid pottery activities for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for one week to evaluate the patient's progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up after a fall and chest pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain, thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during physical activity.
Genitourinary: No issues reported.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Advised to monitor weight daily and contact the doctor if there is a gain of 3 pounds in 2 days.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed dietary modifications.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and groin. The pain is intermittent and severe when it occurs. The patient reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain with minimal relief. He feels nauseated but has not vomited. The patient has a history of kidney stones and his father also had kidney stones.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports right-sided abdominal pain and nausea.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Right kidney stone (acute nephrolithiasis).

PLAN

1. Encourage the patient to push fluids to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. The patient may continue to take Tylenol for breakthrough pain.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to use when urinating to catch the stone for analysis.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks to check on the patient's progress. If symptoms have not improved, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient should contact the doctor if symptoms worsen or if there are any concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for approximately 6 weeks, which started as a blister after wearing tight shoes. The patient noticed a foul smell, yellow drainage, and the blister becoming unroofed with soft, mushy skin underneath. He has been on antibiotics for 6 days, with some initial improvement, but now reports the wound has turned black around the edges and he is experiencing calf cramping. He also reports a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle, which is hot to touch. The patient's blood sugars have been trending higher in the past few weeks, with occasional spikes up to 500.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently hiked a new trail. He has a new pair of diabetic shoes and inserts, which he changes every 3-4 months.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever of 99.7 and chills prior to starting antibiotics.
Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports coughing and difficulty catching breath when walking around the house.
Skin: Patient reports non-healing right foot ulcer.
Musculoskeletal: Reports calf cramping and pain.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Not provided
Heart rate: Not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

Foot: 2x2 cm necrotic wound on right heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, erythemia, and odor. No bony exposure.
Vascular: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
Pain: No pain upon pressing the affected area of the wound.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer, right foot
2. Diabetes with recent poor blood sugar control
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have discussed the current symptoms and plan with the patient. We will order a test to check blood supply for the wound. I will perform a debridement today in the office and obtain a culture to determine if a change in antibiotic therapy is needed. The patient will continue his current antibiotic course, and we will monitor the redness and swelling in his calf closely. I will see the patient again in 7 days for follow-up. In the meantime, the patient is advised to follow up with his endocrinologist to address his recent poor blood sugar control and maintain a hemoglobin A1c below 7.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors and recently going hunting. Patient noticed a tick bite on the right knee over a week ago, which has been burning and causing discomfort.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, body aches.
Musculoskeletal: Reports typical arthritic pain, no new joint pain.
Neurological: Reports headache and general malaise since tick bite.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension: Controlled with lisinopril.
Diabetes: Controlled with metformin.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Not reported
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion in right knee. Pain to palpation of right anterior knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Possible Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with a tick bite and bull's-eye rash on right knee.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks.

2. Hypertension.
- Continue lisinopril 20 mg once daily.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
- Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control.

4. Kidney function.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order basic metabolic panel to assess kidney function.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
